text:
Configured content negotiation. Works fine with HTML files.
Did the exact same thing for a PHP file, but it won't serve up the file.
Created tmp.php.var, tmp.php.en and tmp.php.fr. Also tried to use tmp.en.php, 
but same result.
If you select the above URL with tmp.php you will get a 404 (In the correct 
language :-)
However, if you put in tmp.php.var it will serve you the right language page!
But tmp.php.var just contains the URI statements - no code.
Since I set it up exactly as the html, and the html content negotiation works I 
assume it's either an undocumented setup problem or a bug.

PS: No answers from the newsgroups, nor on the web. Fonud one other person with 
the same problem, but no solution.

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Hmmm... I can't remember seeing your question on the newsgroup, but perhaps
I missed it.

You ommitted a crucial configuration detail here: do you have
Options Multiviews
set correctly for the relevant directory?

I posted to newsgroups alt.comp.lang.php and alt.apache.configuration. Are 
these wrong?

Anyway, when activating MultiViews on the particular directories, it does 
indeed work.
However, I have a .var file. The doc clearly says you have 2 
possibilities: .var files or MultiViews.
And as I said, the .var file worked fine for .html files, but not for .php
The MultiViews works fine for both, but isn't MultiViews a lot slower than .var 
files?

And the question remains: Why doesn't the .var file work for php pages?
creator: svdbeek@rivinfo.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Really simple.  Var files work without multiviews, -only- if the client
  requests the var file itself (e.g. index.php.var).

  If you use multiviews, Apache performs a wildcard search on the given
  request name.  If it hits on a .var file, it selects from -all- the mime 
  choices present in the .var file.  If it hits on other files (.en, .fr etc)
  it adds those specific mime choices as well.  Apache then attempts to serve
  the best-match, or depending on the ForceLanguagePriority rules, it will
  deliver an HTTP_MULTIPLE_CHOICES or HTTP_NO_ACCEPTABLE_VARIANT response.

  Because of the wildcard search on the directory, -yes-, multiviews is slower.
  But you aren't asking Apache to serve the named file, you are asking us how
  to find a filename pattern -similar- to the request name (e.g., index.php.var
  -instead- of index.php.)  For that, you must use multiviews.

And yes, alt.apache.configuration is wrong.  That is a bastard newsgroup
that was never properly created and is therefore not widely propigated.
As the apache website says, you should use comp.infosystems.www.servers.unix
